reviewText:
Alright, Dawn of War Dark Crusade, where to begin? This game is by far the best Dawn of War game to date, including Dawn of War 2 and its expansions. If you're an RTS fan, there is little here not to like. (Also, you don't need to own the original Dawn of War OR Winter Assault to enjoy this game)

The gameplay is simple and very fun, you start out with a base and a builder unit, you proceed to make buildings filling various roles such as research, unit creation, and defense. You proceed to make a base and units to defend yourself, and you eventually attack the enemy. You have two resources, power and requisition, power is used for vehicles, upgrades and research, requisition is used for everything. Requisition is easy to get, just capture points across the map and fortify them with listening posts. Power requires you to create power generators, but bases have a limited amount.

Campaign is simple, you pick a race, and you are given a map divided into territories, each territory is provides you honor guard (Elite units to defend your commander) and a planetary requisition bonus (to buy honor guards or defenses for territories, or buildings if you get a specific plot of land) The map is turn based, with you and the 6 other AI going to territories and trying to claim them, when you attack or defend a territory, you are put into a basic RTS battle. If you win, you get/keep the territory, and whatever buildings you made (not research, though) on that territory. You are also rewarded for attacking/defending, allowing you to get wargear for your commander. Your commander can equip new items that can change your playstyle with him/her or simple make them better. Now, the best part of campaign is the stronghold missions, these missions are when you attack another race's main territory, so instead of destroy the enemy HQ, you are presented other tasks, such as destroy these artillery units to stop part of the map being bombarded or kill this commander and get these soldiers to fight for you. Strongholds are very long, hard and entertaining.

The game has a nice selection of races, each filling a playstyle.
Tau = Strong ranged units, good offense
Eldar = Stealth based, fast moving
Orks = Melee swarm
Imperial Guard = Ranged Swarm, great tanks
Space Marines = All around, good melee and ranged
Chaos = Kinda like Space Marines, Melee focused
Necrons = Slow as hell, turtling, but can be near unstoppable when they do attack

Multiplayer and Skirmishing is fun, pretty basic for an RTS but with bots or people, and your own rules.

The graphics and sounds are nice, the graphics show battles in their full glory, with colorful explosions and blood flying from units, and the sound includes powerful gunfire and units yelling in battle. Not much more to be said, the game looks pretty and sounds like war. The soundtrack I do give a shoutout to, its very nicely done.

The only real thing I have a problem with this game is the crashing I get. Sometimes in a match or on the menus my game just freezes up or crashes on me, its not common, but commen enough to add it to this review.

I think RTS or Warhammer fans will really like this game, given you didn't buy it already, 9/10, great game, but some crashing and freezing stops it from being perfect.
Also check out the mods for this game, some of them are very nifty.

Dark Crusade was probably my favorite RTS throughout my college years.  While my friends were busy playing Starcraft, commanding the forces of Terrans, Protoss, and Zerg, I was busy fighting wars in the 41st Millennium, taking on foes ten times my greater and defeating them with honor and earning glory.  This was also the version of Warhammer 40K's Dawn of War series that got me into modding, giving me a sweet, sweet taste of what the penultimate prize of Modding experience would be promised to me upon getting Soulstorm.

If you've ever gotten the previous two, Dawn of War and Winter Assault, you'd know gameplay-wise that nothing's really changed.  However, with the addition of two new factions; the popular Necrons and the mysteriuos Tau Empire; and new units for all other factions (including Grey Knights for the Blood Ravens, which remains my favorite unit choice to this day), it definitely shines in front of its predecessors.  That, and with an awesome campaign where you can play not just one but all seven factions, promising continuous replayability even after you've beaten the campaign once...there's nothing here that's  not to like.

I'd be a fool not to recommend Dark Crusade.  Any RTS player would be a fool to deny that this game stood the test of time.  Stop reading the review, fork out some cash or grab that debit/credit card, and get the sodding game.  The best part about it all is that the multiplayer options are compatible with all versions and are standalone, so you only need one game to have fun.  I recommend giving it a go, it's worth it.  Let's keep this game alive.  For the Emperor!

reviewText:
Dark Crusade is an improvement on the mechanics of Dawn of War and adds new factions, units, and a world map-based conquest mode as the campaign in the game.  For those of us who enjoyed standard scenarios and multiplayer this is entirely an improvement.  Unfortunately, for those of us who were more caught up in the story-based campaigns where a story unfolded before you as you played, that feature no longer exists.

The world map does offer a few advantages that I will admit are enjoyable.  First off, you feel more like a true commander as opposed to a company leader in the prior Dawn of War iterations.  You decided on where and when battles will take place and often those decisions are based on which provinces offer the most requisition (currency) and benefits for your units.  The enemy also acts with the same goals and will actively invade your territory if it sees fit, bringing the battle to you.

The unfortunate part to this, in addition to the loss of a well developed story from earlier campaigns, most of your battles end up being frantic zerg fights where you churn out your units and upgrades as fast as possible and slam them into the enemy until they are dead.  Obviously, the old strategies do apply, and the classic rock-paper-scissors aspects of the units remain, but I myself always felt more caught up accomplishing objectives and advancing the story.

It was a toss up for me, as you may have guessed after reading the above, but I have decided that I'm going to recommend this game since it will satisfy previous DoW players who enjoyed the basic scenarios even if the heavily story-based campaign is gone.

reviewText: Dark Crusade was, in my opinion, the best game of the Dawn of War series. It gave players more freedom than the previous two games with its multiple factions, while not suffering from the recycled concepts and poor storyline/voice acting of Soulstorm. The RISK style dynamic is one that I have found inherently fascinating, and one that I hope that Total War: Warhammer will exploit in the future. My personal highlight of the game, and probably the series overall, were the stronghold assaults. With entertaining storylines and objectives that make it feel very much like a special mission in the tabletop game, I found them to be a refreshing and rewarding experience. My one gripe is what seems to have been faction favouritism amongst the production team. Multiplayer combat is made less enjoyable when people play as the Eldar, and make their webway gate invisible, warping it all over the map, and forcing you to adopt time-consuming  strategies to beat. Overall, however, the game rates among my personal favourite RTSs.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText:
Dark Crusade is the second expansion to Dawn of War and advertised as a standalone expansion as well. It should however, not really be played as a standalone. The complete absence of any sort of tutorial or incremental introduction of units and technologies makes this an incredibly hard place to start for new players as you're essentially thrown into the deep end from the get go and just hope you learn how to swim before you get overwhelmed. To add insult to injury you can only use the two new races in multi-player unless you already own Dawn of War and Winter Assault.

The two new races are very nice additions however. The Necrons are a pure powerhouse, the immortal machine servants of a long dead empire, serving vicious and hungry gods. In game they play quite differently from the others, ignoring usual resources and tactics their build speed is determined by the number of strategic points you own making them a very slow starter, to compensate their units are unusually tough and sometimes even resurrects themselves upon death. Lategame they transform into a steamroller as even their Headquarters becomes a flying, teleporting doomsday machine.

The second new faction to be introduced is the Tau and they similarly play differently from the old factions although not quite as big a deviation as the Necrons are. The Tau are a strange mix of specialists, heavily armed but poorly armored weapons platforms and a variety of beastly allies. The biggest difference between them and other factions is the lategame choice of either going to the heavily armed but poorly armed weapons platforms or the huge beast allies they can also summon as choosing one path excludes the other.

The single-player changes gear from the previous installments and replaces the linear and scripted missions of Dawn of War and Winter Assault with an open campaign map in a Grand Strategy style. Each faction starts with a stronghold province and must conquer the rest of the map as you play along gaining various bonuses from their conquests including various pieces of wargear for their leader. The problem with this concept is all the maps in between the various strongholds are just plain boring, both in attack an defense. Although the map changes it all plays much the same and it comes down to pure grind very quickly.

The stronghold attacks however is where the game gets interesting. Challenging maps with multiple sub-objectives and small video sequences before and after makes them the only bright side of the new campaign.

In terms of graphics and sound it maintains the same quality as the main game. A thunderhammer still makes a satisfying thump when impacting a traitor's breastplate and the Ork's still scream out their one word with relentless fervor.

That feel that comes from the WH40K universe still exists, but the grind of the campaign makes it have much less of an impact than in the original. Still a good expansion, just not an exceptional one and definitely not one to be played as a standalone game.

reviewText:
This is a must have game for any fan of Warhammer 40,000.

This game got me started with the fandom and has been a motivation for finding a better RTS title over Star Craft.

DOW: Dark Crusade is a 2nd expansion to the Dawn of War series.  yet it introduces a more dynamic and unique single player campaign.  Which allows you to select one of the six factions and begin your conquest of the planet Kronus.  Each newly conquered section grants a new powerful unit, resources and upgrades for both yoru army and your commander.

The Combat system introduces typical ranged combat from rapid fire weapons, bombarding artillery and flame throwers.  BUt what really stands out is the melee combat.  Where squads of up to 12 or more engage hand to hand.  Many combatants will end with a finishing move, either putting a boot to the face or a pistol style execution.

Size and scale are impressive in the game.  As we watch massive war tanks support the ground troops or watch the epic duel between two titanic demi gods.

Gravity matters in this game.  So if you hear or see an artillery shell land in the middle of your army, don't be surprised if you see them take to the air.  Don't feel ashamed if you see your infantry get kicked like a soft ball by the demi gods on the field.  But feel honored when you see your captain plant his hammer into said demi god's head with a thunderous BOOM!

The game is a typical Real Time Strategy (RTS) title, which means players must amass resources for buying troops and building facilities too upgrade current units and buy new more powerful ones.  The only difference with resource gather is capturing strategic points and building power generators.  So you don't need to worry about mining gold or chopping trees here.

The Community has been very generous with offering mods which allow gamers too try variety of custom made units, abilites and maps as well as alternating banners and badges for your units.

The original DAWN OF WAR trilogy is a must have for anyone who enjoys RTS with range and melee combat.  Likewise for those who are either familiar or unaware with the Warhammer 40,000 franchise.

reviewText:
Dark Crusade sets you in the over-the-top-ridiculousness that is Dawn of War. The Campaign is narrated by one of the most coolest narrators I've ever listened to. I'd look up his name for this review, but it's 5am.

As you begin and end your campaign your adventers will be narrated in an epic voice, and you can immerse yourself into the world of Dawn of War. The cutscenes are whimsical and magical in a way I can't describe, like with the Orks, and the Necrons, the game presents itself with a certain type of charm that I can't forget. Dawn of War 2 didn't give me the same kind of character and gameplay that this game delivers. Dawn of War - Dark Crusade brings you on an epic adventure, to an epic Campaign. The game's narrator makes your actions feel truly noble, brutal, or just downright awesome. The gameplay can't be compared to something like starcraft or command&conquer, it is a truly unique way of presenting RTS with requisition and relic resources. It's simple, makes some sense, and effective.

The gameplay itself centers it's focus on your units and their various personalities. Like with the Imperial Officers shooting their own soldiers to gain morale, or the awesome Necrons and their units. The game's Campaign is just fantastic and epic, with a charisma that is almost on par with the Disney movies, but for gamers who love Dawn of War. Dawn of War-Dark Crusade, a game I can't forget.

Picture a game of Risk. Now imagine that everytime you attacked a territory or were attacked you had to play out an RTS game with how powerful you are based on the troop points you had going into it. It's a standalone expansion to the original dawm of war with almost all the major factions and a variety of different play styles. One playthrough I went Necron using my Crypt Lord and fully upgraded monolith to teleport around the map as an army of two and obliterate the enemies key structures. The next time I played Tau making squads of stealth suits that would divide and conquer the map causing the enemies main force to always be in the wrong position.

Grab it through a sale or any other kind of bundle and it will be well worth your time and money.

This game is truly epic, and if you're thinking about getting it, I would ADVISE it, this is a fantastic game with hundreds of hours of fun to be had. In the Emperors name, you will purchase this game.
Whether you're a w40k fan or a real time strategy game fan, you'll love Dark Crusade.
It's incredibly fun, you'll be charging into battle with your enemies, constantly repeating anything your units say.
If you've played the original game of Dawn of War, you'll definitely feel at home with Dark Crusade, it's more of the same but much much better. Based on a world map that you can invade other provinces instead of following a campaign story is much better.
The W40k universe is so huge and so fantastic that you'll be fascinated by the Imperium of Man with their Soldiers, or the God Emperors Space Marines, the dark necrons, or Chaos Space Marines... Or perhaps the Eldar or even the technological Tau with their Greater Good philosophy (or the orcs... but who likes them? ;) Haha).

Set on the planet Kronus, you'll find yourself in the middle of a bloody war, a dark crusade. Where one faction will triumph and the total annihilation of all others. Make sure that it is YOUR faction. You can play as any of the W40k factions that you've grown to know and love... Or at least you'll come to know and love if you haven't experienced a W40k game yet though.

Don't let the franchise fool you though, it's very easy to get into the frachnise, this was the first W40k game I've ever played (back in 2006) and I've played all of them since (and the ones before). I'm not a fan of the figures or the board game though, even though the games are based on it... Shh! Plus the CGI movies/clips are awesome. The whole W40k universe is fascinating.

Anyway, about the game.
It's a typical real time strategy game, construct buildings, construct units from buildings, defeat the enemy. That's a simple run down of it anyway. All of the maps are static too. So when you've built a base in a province, if you're invaded, your base will be exactly the same as it was when you first built it. But any buildings destroyed in the next battle will be gone, but also new buildings will stay obviously. So definitely plan ahead when you first build in a province.

(SPOILER: I've found myself trapping an enemy in a small corner of a map and building a huge base all over the map before I destroy them, so that my huge base is persistant if anyone invades it... But that's kinda cheating hehe)

It's a very fun game, but don't take my word for it, check out videos of it on YouTube and many of the other reviews of this game.
If you enjoyed this game, be sure to get SoulStorm, it's practically an expansion of this game and includes another faction, instead of battling all over Kronus, you'll be battling across an entire solar system on a variety of planets instead!

Deep under the central desert of Kronus, a vast honeycomb of skull-lined tunnels and funeral chambers house the awakening Necron menace. Eons ago, these were the boulevards and squares of a great necropolis built to house the bones of the races who had fallen to the Necrons, and ultimately were where the Necrons themselves retire to spend eternity. Over millions of years, sand and rock had covered it all until ill-fated excavations awoke the deathless.
Play any of seven races, striving for control over Kronus. Take other races' strongholds by winning challenging battles on various maps individually associated with the respective strongholds.

New Races
Take command of two new playable races: Tau and Necron to unleash massive carnage across the frontlines of battle.

Expanded multiplayer
Dominate opponents online across 12 new multiplayer maps - with up to 8 players battling it out for supremacy.

Deep single player campaign
Conquer the planet of Kronus any way you choose - leading any one of seven races on an epic crusade through an all-new, non-linear single player campaign where you can experience unique storylines from each race's perspective.

Customization
Customize your hero's weapons, items and abilities as he grows in power and influence. Personalize your army with a variety of insignias, squad colors, banners and names.

Verdict: I would highly recommend this to anybody who enjoys RTS games, 40K fan or not.

Not too sure what to say about this one. with this one they have changed the game entirely since Winter Assult and instead you are on a map. You have to take over territories, each giving a boon of somekind and the game is over when you have driven all other races off the planet.

2. Certain missions are far more than simply (destroy enemy HQ) and involve more difficult tasks like collecting a number of units or destroying certain objectives. All this makes it feel like they actually put thought into it.

3. Invading the Homebase. The homebase battles are absolutely EPIC! Definantly buy this if you have the others.

reviewText: I really like this game and I just finished the campaign a moment ago (for the Blood Ravens). Dawn of War Dark Crusade is an expansion to Relic's real time strategy game Dawn of War, which is set in the Warhammer 40, 000 universe of table top wargames. I highly recommend it to any real time stategy fan who loves the grittines and toughness of battles which are primarily set in a distopian future where every alien you meet wants to kill you and eat you for jujubes :D, and that's not all; Your government, which is the Grand Imperium of Man, constantly drafts new recruits in the billions in order to sacrifice to The Emeperor, who uses His powerful psychic mind in order to stave the forces of Super Hell (or Chaos for short) which constantly gobbles up any known dangerous substances in order to get high for the dark gods. The 7 major races are The Blood Ravens; The Emperor's own space marines who came to the planet Kronus to search for the secrets of their lost history. The Ork's or should I say 'Da Orks', only come for the tendency of following their Ork Chieftains for the sake of the Waaaagh!!!! in order to satuate their cravings for constant battle. The Eldar, a mysterious alien race which are a splinters of their former empire 10, 000 years prior to the 41st millenium, have come to Kronus in order to stop their ancient enemies, known as the Necrons, from rising from their tomb worlds and purging the galaxy clean of all sentient life. The Necrons were metallic warriors who slumbered eons ago iduring the aftermath, which in Eldar legend was in the aftermath of the so called 'War in Heaven'. Then there are the imperial guard, chaos and the tau (my favourite), and for that YOU can explore for yourself. For the 4 races I've mentioned there is a ton of lore to explore and unfortunately I cannot tell you all of it. If you think Halo, Startrek  and Starwars had tons of lore, you have never read the Lore of 40k, it is just a massive game world that you need to delve into. As for this game I give a solid 9/10. Please relic in the name of the emperor, where is Dawn of War 3?

reviewText:
Dark Crusade was probably my favorite RTS throughout my college years. While my friends were busy playing Starcraft, commanding the forces of Terrans, Protoss, and Zerg, I was busy fighting wars in the 41st Millennium, taking on foes ten times my greater and defeating them with honor and earning glory. This was also the version of Warhammer 40K's Dawn of War series that got me into modding, giving me a sweet, sweet taste of what the penultimate prize of Modding experience would be promised to me upon getting Soulstorm.

If you've ever gotten the previous two, Dawn of War and Winter Assault, you'd know gameplay-wise that nothing's really changed. However, with the addition of two new factions; the popular Necrons and the mysteriuos Tau Empire; and new units for all other factions (including Grey Knights for the Blood Ravens, which remains my favorite unit choice to this day), it definitely shines in front of its predecessors. That, and with an awesome campaign where you can play not just one but all seven factions, promising continuous replayability even after you've beaten the campaign once...there's nothing here that's not to like.

I'd be a fool not to recommend Dark Crusade. Any RTS player would be a fool to deny that this game stood the test of time. Stop reading the review, fork out some cash or grab that debit/credit card, and get the sodding game. The best part about it all is that the multiplayer options are compatible with all versions and are standalone, so you only need one game to have fun. I recommend giving it a go, it's worth it. Let's keep this game alive. For the Emperor

reviewText:
I Played this game, from release to now.

Game has a wonderful array of units and armies which creates a unique universe to fight in. With 7 playable races and a million ways to play them you're not likely to run out of ways to kill stuff in this game. Best way to play the game is with 2 or 3 mates whilst in skype calls. You can really get involved in the competitiveness of base building and accumulating an army. Whether your making a turtle style base,crawling with turrets and snipers or rushing with bulky green aliens the game is fun at any stage of play from the first seconds to the 15 minutes where someone runs into your barely prepared base with an army of necrons.

Campaign is just a series of skirmishes and leaves something to be desired in the area of voice acting and storyline, however it doesn't mean it's not fun. You can have fun in moving from battle to battle. The campaign is a solid

The Game has a high degree of unit customization and army painting that makes your army unique to you, the more effort you put into the look of your army the more you can get behind it.

Graphics are great and still hold after 9 years! pictures don't show just how good the game looks.

All in all the game is in my opinion one of a kind and an unforgettable RTS experience. If RTS and army building is what gets you hard then this game will leave you with a raging erection.

Warhammer 40k Dark Crusade is the 3rd entry into the Dawn of War series and its a strong contender in the RTS market despite not being as mainstream as the Starcraft or Stronghold series. If you enjoy games like Company of Heroes and Starcraft then this is a can't miss title.

The game is set on the planet Kronus where the Imperial Guard rule in the name of the Emperor but all is not well on Kronus. The Ork invasion has begun anew on this planet and with all the fighting above the ancient killing machines known as the Necron have awaken which in turn has caused the Tau to appear on the planet in an effort to stop them from annihilating all life on the planet. Of course all this extra violence has attracted the attention of the Blood God of Chaos attention and brought the Chaos Marines onto Kronus. And with the Chaos Marines the Eldar quickly came in tow to stop them from ressurecting more demons and overtaking more planets. The Space Marines (namely the Blood Ravens) are ordered to cleanse the planet now for it is considered overrun with the Alien, the Unclean, and the Heretic. Upon their arrival on the planet they are told their are precious artifacts on Kronus that must be reclaimed at all costs and thus order the Imperial Guard to evacuate from Kronus in order for them to purge Kronus and reclaim the artifacts. The Guard promptly refuses and sparks an intense war with the Blood Ravens. This all quickly turns into a nasty open war.
How this war plays out however is solely up to you however. The game gives you a decent background for each race and the events leading to the war but it has not true canon story beyond that. Your campaign mode consists of picking 1 of several races (Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, Chaos Marines, Tau, or Necrons) and then using them to conquer the entire map. The campaign starts off on the world screen where you can reinforce your territories launch attacks or upgrade your Honor Guard, which are essentially free beefed up versions of your basic units, as well as upgrade your commander unit with Wargear, items that add health attack or other bonus abilities to your commander unit. Each race has its own Stronghold which if taken will kick them from the game for that campaign. Capture all strongholds to win.
All in all the game looks great despite some age, it sounds great and has a decent soundtrack and its positively steeped in lore for every race. Theres dozens of novels written on this series. I highly recommend this game to any and all fans of RTS games. Gotta cut this one short since Steam wont let me write any more about this game! For the Emperor!

Warhammer 40k Dark Crusade is the 3rd entry into the Dawn of War series and its a strong contender in the RTS market despite not being as mainstream as the Starcraft or Stronghold series. If you enjoy games like Company of Heroes and Starcraft then this is a can't miss title.

The game is set on the planet Kronus where the Imperial Guard rule in the name of the Emperor but all is not well on Kronus. The Ork invasion has begun anew on this planet and with all the fighting above the ancient killing machines known as the Necron have awaken which in turn has caused the Tau to appear on the planet in an effort to stop them from annihilating all life on the planet. Of course all this extra violence has attracted the attention of the Blood God of Chaos attention and brought the Chaos Marines onto Kronus. And with the Chaos Marines the Eldar quickly came in tow to stop them from ressurecting more demons and overtaking more planets. The Space Marines (namely the Blood Ravens) are ordered to cleanse the planet now for it is considered overrun with the Alien, the Unclean, and the Heretic. Upon their arrival on the planet they are told their are precious artifacts on Kronus that must be reclaimed at all costs and thus order the Imperial Guard to evacuate from Kronus in order for them to purge Kronus and reclaim the artifacts. The Guard promptly refuses and sparks an intense war with the Blood Ravens. This all quickly turns into a nasty open war.
How this war plays out however is solely up to you however. The game gives you a decent background for each race and the events leading to the war but it has not true canon story beyond that. Your campaign mode consists of picking 1 of several races (Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, Chaos Marines, Tau, or Necrons) and then using them to conquer the entire map. The campaign starts off on the world screen where you can reinforce your territories launch attacks or upgrade your Honor Guard, which are essentially free beefed up versions of your basic units, as well as upgrade your commander unit with Wargear, items that add health attack or other bonus abilities to your commander unit. Each race has its own Stronghold which if taken will kick them from the game for that campaign. Capture all strongholds to win.
All in all the game looks great despite some age, it sounds great and has a decent soundtrack and its positively steeped in lore for every race. Theres dozens of novels written on this series. I highly recommend this game to any and all fans of RTS games. Gotta cut this one short since Steam wont let me write any more about this game! For the Emperor!

If you are a fan of either the Warhammer 40K universe, or RTS games, or both, then this game is for you. Out of all the Dawn of War games (excluding Dawn of War 2), this one is hands down my favorite. I have sunk a LOT of hours into this game, and I'm only about a quarter of the way finished with it.

Here's how the game plays: You pick a race (Space Marines, Chaos, Tau, Ethereal, Orks, Imperial Guard) at the start of the game. Each race has their own strengths and weaknesses. My personal favorite are the Space Marines, who are very versatile and can easily adapt to any situation. Once you pick a race, the game begins. It is set up like a board game, similar to Risk. Each race takes a turn, and on your turn you can choose where you want to move to. Where you choose determines what race you will fight in that area. Every territory also rewards you with Honor Guard, which are elite units (VERY powerful compared to your regular units). In addition to this, there are a couple territories that have special abilities, such as the Spaceport that lets you attack anywhere, or Forward Base which lets you start matches with some buildings already made. The game continues on like this, with you attacking and defending. Your commander unit also acquires War Gear as you play, which makes them even more powerful.

The real combat of this game is in the attacking or defending phase. The game plays as standard RTS fare. You gather resources, build structures, and grow your army. There is a lot of variety within a single race, which really helps to mix up the gameplay. You take over resource points and fortify them as your forces clash with your opponent. Once your army is built up enough, then you can obliterate your opponent and win the territory. Two things are important to remember, though. First, the way you leave a territory is what you will come back to when you are defending it. If you fortify it heavily, then you will be hard to defeat when the battle comes back to that area. Secondly, the special territories all have unique battles. The Spaceport, for example, has you gathering special units scattered across the map. The first side to collect 6 of these wins.

Graphics wise, this game is behind what you'd expect from a modern RTS game, but it gets the job done very well. The units are all very detailed, and pleasing to look at when you zoom the camera in. The only downside is that the terrain looks a little bland sometimes. However, this game is not about looking pretty, it's about the battles. And combat is really well done in this game. If you've played the other Dawn of War games, then you know how it goes. It's really cool to see the animations of units in combat, they don't just pummel each other until a health bar is gone, there is interaction between clashing forces.

In addition to the campaign, there is a skirmish mode that you can play to your heart's content. If you and a buddy have this game, then you can also jump online and play against each other in online multiplayer. All in all, this is a great game. Don't let Steam fool you, I've been playing this long before I bought it on here, and my hours in it are easily 200+. I like replaying the game as the other races to see what I've missed. If you like Warhammer 40K or RTS games, this one's for you. If you aren't sure, then grab it if it goes on sale. Trust me, it's worth it.

In my mind this is the best expansion in the Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War franchise. Dawn of War vanilla was good, yes, but its only drawback was the short single player campaign.

Dark Crusade's single player campaign is designed like a Risk map, where you get a province on a planet and have to wrest control of the planet from the other 6 races (Space Marines, Chaos, Orks, Eldar, Imperial Guard, Tau and Necrons). In each province you have to buiold a base and then destroy the other faction's base. The more provinces you take, the more perks you get for your army (production bonuses, armor for your commander, veteran squads to boost your amry, etc.). It lacks a bit in story, but taking a enemy fortress allows for some narrative.

Again, it is in the multiplayer or skirmish games where this game shines (don't take my word for it based on the amount of hours I played - I already bought the Dawn of War box set and played the crap out of it - for the Emperor!)

Out of all the original dawn of war games, this is my favorite.  Something very simple makes this particular game stand out: fortifying individual areas on the strategic map.  Comparing this to Soulstorm, as they are similar, Dark Crusade eliminates some of the tiresome defenses you run into with Soulstorm.  Constantly fighting over a single piece of land gets old when you start every defense with one building and a servitor.  Compare that with DC starting you with everything but the units you ended the last tactical battle with.  Something small, but it made a big difference to me and kept me coming back.  I also highly recommend Titanium Wars for a mod as it adds tons to the game.
